description: Word 2016 Expert takes users to the next level in document processing.  This series explores how to enhance long documents with episodes that include: creating a table of contents, generating an index, adding footnotes and endnotes, inserting bookmarks and cross references, labeling figures with captions, and citing references for a bibliography. Also covered in long documents is how to create a master document and add sub documents for large projects. Other topics in this series include how to collaborate in Word and through Office 365 online, secure your documents, and add or edit document properties. While Word 2016 Expert is a continuation from the Word 2016 Advanced and Essentials series, episodes can be viewed individually for specific topics or enjoyed in sequence.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate and explain using bookmarks and cross references. Here they show you bookmark specifics like marking a location, naming conventions, and selecting a range of content. Then they look at cross reference specifics like using hyperlinks and choosing what text to display as the cross reference.
episodes.title: Bookmarks and Cross References

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne show you how to insert a table of contents (TOC) into your Word documents. Here they will go over heading levels (styles), TOC templates, map to custom styles for TOC, updating TOC, and removing TOC.

episodes.description: Vonne and Daniel show how to manually mark words and ranges to be included in an index and then how generate the index. They also cover how to auto mark entries from a concordance file, how to update and format an index, and how to remove marked entries.
episodes.title: Create Index

episodes.description: Citing work for use in research or academic papers is very important. In this episode, Vonne and Zach show you how easy Word has made it to add and manage sources, insert citations, and generate and update a bibliography.
episodes.title: Citations and Bibliography

322
00:14:59.980 --> 00:15:03.050
So I come back over to that manage
sources notice that it has been

323
00:15:03.050 --> 00:15:04.710
added in to my master list.

324
00:15:04.710 --> 00:15:09.090
Well I need to bring over Ronnie's and
I will bring over mine and

325
00:15:09.090 --> 00:15:13.100
why not bring over Microsoft
cuz I actually sighted their,

326
00:15:13.100 --> 00:15:18.710
I put their website in for how to add
a bibliography as a source for fun.

327
00:15:18.710 --> 00:15:20.510
Went ahead and got that over there.

328
00:15:20.510 --> 00:15:22.640
Let's click close.

329
00:15:22.640 --> 00:15:23.580
Now if I scroll down,

330
00:15:23.580 --> 00:15:28.300
let's pretend that we need to have this
sentence right here as a citation.

331
00:15:28.300 --> 00:15:30.030
Cursor where I want to put in,

332
00:15:30.030 --> 00:15:33.740
now all of my sources are right here in
this drop down for me to choose from.

333
00:15:33.740 --> 00:15:36.310
Well this is, I'm going to quote,
this is Ronnie's quote.

334
00:15:37.650 --> 00:15:43.913
Put it in there, put his last name coma
the date, fantastic you keep on going.

335
00:15:43.913 --> 00:15:46.851
So you now have the place
where you can add your

336
00:15:46.851 --> 00:15:49.634
own sources that weren't in master list,

337
00:15:49.634 --> 00:15:54.685
you know how to manage sources from your
collective list in to your document.

338
00:15:54.685 --> 00:15:57.472
You just put your cursor and
start doing your citations.

339
00:15:57.472 --> 00:15:59.218
This is where hey, you know what?

340
00:15:59.218 --> 00:16:00.595
Teacher told me that it was AP and

341
00:16:00.595 --> 00:16:02.739
now they've told me I gotta
change it to Chicago.

342
00:16:02.739 --> 00:16:03.762
>> Dash darn.

343
00:16:03.762 --> 00:16:05.400
>> Right, well look at how easy that is.

344
00:16:05.400 --> 00:16:08.110
You just change it and
[SOUND] it changes all the punctuation.

345
00:16:08.110 --> 00:16:09.885
>> Wait a minute,
that's too easy, confound it!

346
00:16:09.885 --> 00:16:13.410
>> [LAUGH] I know, right,
it's pretty amazing.

347
00:16:13.410 --> 00:16:17.610
So I could go back and forth through
different styles, add my citations.

348
00:16:17.610 --> 00:16:18.670
And I have done two.

349
00:16:18.670 --> 00:16:20.810
We'll do one more just for fun.

350
00:16:20.810 --> 00:16:24.850
Alice was not a bit hurt, which is good,
you don't want to have that.

351
00:16:24.850 --> 00:16:27.350
And let's just go ahead and
give myself a quote.

352
00:16:27.350 --> 00:16:30.150
Perfect, got everything, wonderful.

353
00:16:30.150 --> 00:16:32.320
Go through my entire document.

354
00:16:32.320 --> 00:16:37.670
Now let's go jump to the bottom, and
we will now insert the bibliography.

355
00:16:37.670 --> 00:16:42.270
You could put this as a Ctrl+Enter and
put this on your own page if you want.

356
00:16:42.270 --> 00:16:44.110
Cursor where you want it to generate.

357
00:16:44.110 --> 00:16:45.270
Go to Bibliography, and

358
00:16:45.270 --> 00:16:50.220
then it shows you is it's going to be a
bibliography, references, or works cited.

359
00:16:50.220 --> 00:16:53.140
Now at first, I'm like, well,
they're all the same thing.

360
00:16:53.140 --> 00:16:55.640
Well, had to go out to the Oracle.

361
00:16:55.640 --> 00:16:58.480
Had to go to the Internet and
be like, are they?

362
00:16:58.480 --> 00:16:59.740
That was the wrong swipe.

363
00:16:59.740 --> 00:17:03.040
That was the swiping over to
my actual Apple computer.

364
00:17:03.040 --> 00:17:06.750
I was supposed to go down to here and
say, though, so what's the difference?

365
00:17:06.750 --> 00:17:09.550
And I found just a quick one right here.

366
00:17:09.550 --> 00:17:11.960
Work cited is referred to as references.

367
00:17:11.960 --> 00:17:14.170
Work cited and
bibliography are not the same.

368
00:17:15.400 --> 00:17:20.310
Okay, but it's talking about
the MLA usually uses work cited and

369
00:17:20.310 --> 00:17:23.790
that APA is using references.

370
00:17:23.790 --> 00:17:26.500
So again,
maybe this is that whole back to.

371
00:17:26.500 --> 00:17:29.215
Well just cuz the Internet says
it doesn't mean that's correct.

372
00:17:29.215 --> 00:17:33.320
[LAUGH] Consult your English teacher
as to which one and to which style and

373
00:17:33.320 --> 00:17:37.130
what specific topic or
heading that you want it to say.

374
00:17:37.130 --> 00:17:43.090
But I just wanted to throw that in there
for a little fun, but you pick which one.

375
00:17:43.090 --> 00:17:45.540
I'm gonna choose bibliography.

376
00:17:45.540 --> 00:17:49.470
I choose it and it just,
poop, pops it right in.

377
00:17:49.470 --> 00:17:51.581
It's like that's amazing.

378
00:17:51.581 --> 00:17:54.190
>> It's amazing.
>> All of it is all in there and

379
00:17:54.190 --> 00:17:55.290
it's ready to go.

380
00:17:55.290 --> 00:17:57.660
But do notice one thing.

381
00:17:57.660 --> 00:18:01.970
Microsoft is being used
in my bibliography.

382
00:18:01.970 --> 00:18:05.780
But I didn't actually cite
anything from Microsoft, did I?

383
00:18:05.780 --> 00:18:09.211
I chose yours, I did Memos,
Smith and Wong, but

384
00:18:09.211 --> 00:18:11.987
I did not use Microsoft in my document.

385
00:18:11.987 --> 00:18:13.941
So that's one of those, okay, well,

386
00:18:13.941 --> 00:18:17.927
if I didn't cite anything from it, I
don't need to have it in my bibliography.

387
00:18:17.927 --> 00:18:21.355
It's really only supposed to have what
you had in the document, correct?

388
00:18:21.355 --> 00:18:25.260
Cuz it is pulling from all of the sources.

389
00:18:25.260 --> 00:18:26.630
I'm clicking on managed sources,

390
00:18:26.630 --> 00:18:30.370
all the sources that you told
it to use in your current list.

391
00:18:30.370 --> 00:18:35.620
So see here, it doesn't have a check box,
it doesn't say cited source next to it.

392
00:18:35.620 --> 00:18:38.490
So it's letting me know
that I didn't use this, so

393
00:18:38.490 --> 00:18:42.030
if I didn't use it, I probably
shouldn't put it in the bibliography.

394
00:18:42.030 --> 00:18:44.880
So you come over to your current list and
you just delete it.

395
00:18:44.880 --> 00:18:47.360
Now don't worry, it's not gonna
be deleted on the left side,

396
00:18:47.360 --> 00:18:51.120
cuz I'm selecting it on
the right on the current list.

397
00:18:51.120 --> 00:18:55.180
Delete that, and
it takes it out of my current list, but

398
00:18:55.180 --> 00:18:58.020
it does not delete it from my master list.

399
00:18:58.020 --> 00:19:00.820
So if you had come over here and
clicked the delete,

400
00:19:00.820 --> 00:19:05.580
you will be deleting it from all of Word,
your master list.

401
00:19:05.580 --> 00:19:08.230
That doesn't mean that it's deleting
it from any documents that you had,

402
00:19:08.230 --> 00:19:09.510
like insert it into.

403
00:19:09.510 --> 00:19:11.130
It doesn't go that far.

404
00:19:11.130 --> 00:19:14.958
It just means that you won't
have that as a choice for

405
00:19:14.958 --> 00:19:19.000
the ones you could put into your document.

406
00:19:19.000 --> 00:19:21.594
So I have deleted that, but
now I need to update this.

407
00:19:21.594 --> 00:19:24.810
And this is, again, maybe I went back and
put a new source in.

408
00:19:24.810 --> 00:19:31.294
I made a new cite, I've done changes
within my document to my citing.

409
00:19:31.294 --> 00:19:33.900
Needed the bibliography to reflect that.

410
00:19:33.900 --> 00:19:36.840
You click it once,
it is a field, just like before,

411
00:19:36.840 --> 00:19:41.480
you can update the citations
bibliography right there.

412
00:19:41.480 --> 00:19:45.280
Notice how Microsoft is no
longer part of my bibliography

413
00:19:45.280 --> 00:19:48.820
because I didn't use it and it's not
in my source list for this document.

414
00:19:48.820 --> 00:19:52.940
So a lot of really cool
things that you can do

415
00:19:52.940 --> 00:19:56.540
in the bibliography or
citing your information.

416
00:19:56.540 --> 00:19:58.788
My last thing I would probably say is for
me.

417
00:19:58.788 --> 00:20:01.020
What if this is not formatted properly,

418
00:20:01.020 --> 00:20:03.780
maybe I need a little bit more space
between some of my paragraphs.

419
00:20:03.780 --> 00:20:04.840
>> Because you're fickle.

420
00:20:04.840 --> 00:20:07.900
>> I am, and
I'm such a stickler for spacing.

421
00:20:07.900 --> 00:20:09.800
It's a big thing for me.

422
00:20:09.800 --> 00:20:11.396
Actually this spacing is just fine.

423
00:20:11.396 --> 00:20:12.280
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah it's fine.

424
00:20:12.280 --> 00:20:15.440
>> But I could select this all,
I can come over and

425
00:20:15.440 --> 00:20:17.860
format it just the way
I would anything else.

426
00:20:17.860 --> 00:20:20.190
I can go into my line spacing options.

427
00:20:20.190 --> 00:20:24.320
Maybe go ahead and bump that up to like
24 points after paragraph, gives a little

428
00:20:24.320 --> 00:20:28.780
bit extra room, change some different
things then I can go through this.

429
00:20:28.780 --> 00:20:33.837
Now the other thing that you could

430
00:20:33.837 --> 00:20:39.990
do is if I wanted to say My Cited Sources.

431
00:20:39.990 --> 00:20:43.720
Which is probably obviously not correct
in how you're supposed to do things.

432
00:20:43.720 --> 00:20:48.480
[LAUGH] But I'm trying to get to,
you could create this

433
00:20:48.480 --> 00:20:52.720
as your own bibliography
gallery like this,

434
00:20:52.720 --> 00:20:57.330
My Cited Sources with this
particular spacing of my paragraphs.

435
00:20:57.330 --> 00:20:58.290
If I save that.

436
00:20:58.290 --> 00:20:59.558
>> Customize, it'd be customized.

437
00:20:59.558 --> 00:21:00.530
>> Yeah, exactly.

438
00:21:00.530 --> 00:21:03.470
So you could say,
My Cited Sources, perfect.

439
00:21:03.470 --> 00:21:06.230
It is gonna be part of a building block,
this is one of those,

440
00:21:06.230 --> 00:21:09.710
we talked about this in quick parts
back in Word advanced series.

441
00:21:09.710 --> 00:21:11.430
So if you wanna check that episode out,

442
00:21:11.430 --> 00:21:13.820
there's a lot of great things
about the building blocks.

443
00:21:13.820 --> 00:21:19.390
And all the preformatted generated content
that Word has for you and adding your own.

444
00:21:19.390 --> 00:21:21.010
Click OK.

445
00:21:21.010 --> 00:21:24.490
So now you can see that if I
come over to a new document and

446
00:21:24.490 --> 00:21:26.620
went into my bibliography.

447
00:21:26.620 --> 00:21:31.600
You could see if I scroll down,
there's the one that I made that has my

448
00:21:31.600 --> 00:21:36.120
cited sources and the spacing of how
I'd want to generate the bibliography.

449
00:21:36.120 --> 00:21:44.130
So any customization of an generated
bibliography that you want to remember for

450
00:21:44.130 --> 00:21:49.090
next time,
just save it as your own in the gallery.

451
00:21:49.090 --> 00:21:51.270
So lots of fantastic stuff.

452
00:21:51.270 --> 00:21:54.640
And again, I really wish,
I just turned on iTunes over on my Mac.

453
00:21:54.640 --> 00:21:56.102
Okay, let's [LAUGH].

454
00:21:56.102 --> 00:21:56.878
>> Blue Moon.

455
00:21:56.878 --> 00:22:00.583
[SOUND]
>> I wanted to play us off, right?

456
00:22:00.583 --> 00:22:05.580
Play off a little tune as we end this
episode on citations and bibliographies.

457
00:22:05.580 --> 00:22:06.550
>> Long documents.

458
00:22:06.550 --> 00:22:13.126
Citations and bibliographies, Word 2016
Expert, that's Microsoft Word 2016 Expert.

459
00:22:13.126 --> 00:22:15.420
And there's a lot of video
content in this series.

460
00:22:15.420 --> 00:22:17.275
Make sure you watch every single
one of them, you'll love it.

461
00:22:17.275 --> 00:22:19.380
Vonne, excellent job as always.

462
00:22:19.380 --> 00:22:21.484
And thank you for watching OfficeProTV.

463
00:22:21.484 --> 00:22:24.290
Rmember, a good office
pro is always learning.

464
00:22:24.290 --> 00:22:25.065
I'm Jack Memos.

465
00:22:25.065 --> 00:22:25.627
>> And I'm Vvonne Smith.

466
00:22:25.627 --> 00:22:27.473
>> And we'll see you again real soon.

467
00:22:27.473 --> 00:22:32.754

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Vonne discuss footnotes and endnotes. They cover how to add, format, update, delete, and convert footnotes and/or endnotes in a Word document.
episodes.title: Footnotes and Endnotes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.063 --> 00:00:06.110
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.110 --> 00:00:08.195
Hello, and thank you for
watching OfficeProTV,

3
00:00:08.195 --> 00:00:09.691
helping you learn wherever you go.

4
00:00:09.691 --> 00:00:11.666
I'm your host, Zack Memos,

5
00:00:11.666 --> 00:00:16.570
as we continue on with Microsoft Word
2016 Expert, Long Documents.

6
00:00:16.570 --> 00:00:19.020
Today it's Footnotes and Endnotes!

7
00:00:19.020 --> 00:00:22.450
And Vonne Smith is gonna deliver us the
information that we need, right, Vonne?

8
00:00:22.450 --> 00:00:24.701
>> Yes, I am, thank you so
much for having me.

9
00:00:24.701 --> 00:00:27.443
I like the way you said that,
footnotes and endnotes.

10
00:00:27.443 --> 00:00:29.230
>> [LAUGH]
>> So proper and-

11
00:00:29.230 --> 00:00:30.424
>> Yeah, footnotes, endnotes.

12
00:00:30.424 --> 00:00:33.670
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] footnotes,
endnotes, yes, exactly.

13
00:00:33.670 --> 00:00:36.620
So yes, we're continuing
on with our long documents.

14
00:00:36.620 --> 00:00:40.679
And really, when I say long documents,
it's more like writing reports.

15
00:00:40.679 --> 00:00:41.298
>> Right.

16
00:00:41.298 --> 00:00:46.740
>> I keep thinking about school, where you
had to go ahead and write those reports.

17
00:00:46.740 --> 00:00:49.572
And you had to have all
of your references cited.

18
00:00:49.572 --> 00:00:51.030
And have your table of contents.

19
00:00:51.030 --> 00:00:54.212
All the different things that we have been
going over throughout these episodes.

20
00:00:54.212 --> 00:00:57.358
And then footnotes and
endnotes was another one of those.

21
00:00:57.358 --> 00:01:02.121
Where you had to, if you wanted to
make just like a little note on this

22
00:01:02.121 --> 00:01:07.557
particular sentence or paragraph,
you would put like the superscript one or

23
00:01:07.557 --> 00:01:10.834
some type of symbol at
the end of the sentence.

24
00:01:10.834 --> 00:01:15.810
And then at the bottom of the page, you'd
have to go ahead and put that footnote.

25
00:01:15.810 --> 00:01:18.840
And it had to be formatted properly,
it had to match.

26
00:01:18.840 --> 00:01:20.330
You had to make sure all the numbers.

27
00:01:20.330 --> 00:01:23.320
And if you didn't have
something as beautiful as Word

28
00:01:23.320 --> 00:01:26.580
to guide you along through, it's like,
you have to go back and erase them all and

29
00:01:26.580 --> 00:01:27.570
all that kinda fun stuff.

30
00:01:27.570 --> 00:01:29.473
So it was not so much fun doing it
back in the day on pen and paper.

31
00:01:29.473 --> 00:01:33.790
>> Back in the day, so what different
shapes do the footnote from the endnote,

32
00:01:33.790 --> 00:01:34.680
just briefly?

33
00:01:34.680 --> 00:01:40.355
>> The placement, really, yeah,
a footnote is at the end of a page.

34
00:01:40.355 --> 00:01:44.516
And endnote is at the end
of either a chapter-

35
00:01:44.516 --> 00:01:45.252
>> Or the book.

36
00:01:45.252 --> 00:01:46.081
>> Or the book.

37
00:01:46.081 --> 00:01:46.770
>> Or the report.

38
00:01:46.770 --> 00:01:50.100
>> Yeah, and it just depends on
where they've decided to put it.

39
00:01:50.100 --> 00:01:53.820
All the way in the back of the book or
in that particular chapter.

40
00:01:53.820 --> 00:01:55.265
So I've seen them both ways.

41
00:01:55.265 --> 00:01:55.850
>> Mm-hm.

42
00:01:55.850 --> 00:01:59.016
>> So
I think it's more of a stylistic choice.

43
00:01:59.016 --> 00:02:03.347
I did some research, or, at least,
I went to the oracle of the Internet that

44
00:02:03.347 --> 00:02:07.225
sometimes you don't know if it's right or
wrong.

45
00:02:07.225 --> 00:02:10.998
But it really just said which way,
which one is better,

46
00:02:10.998 --> 00:02:13.260
it really depends on the author.

47
00:02:13.260 --> 00:02:15.295
And how they're wanted to put it.

48
00:02:15.295 --> 00:02:19.641
And also, maybe like the length
of the amount of footnotes or

49
00:02:19.641 --> 00:02:20.855
endnotes that they might have.

50
00:02:20.855 --> 00:02:23.390
If you have a lot of
different things that you're

51
00:02:23.390 --> 00:02:26.090
putting those types of notes
on throughout your page.

52
00:02:26.090 --> 00:02:29.672
Think about if you had six or seven on
a page, that might take up a lot of space-

53
00:02:29.672 --> 00:02:30.295
>> It could.

54
00:02:30.295 --> 00:02:34.307
>> At that particular one, especially
if it's going into more detail, or

55
00:02:34.307 --> 00:02:35.622
a research project, or

56
00:02:35.622 --> 00:02:39.990
talking about whatever type of information
they're wanting to put in there.

57
00:02:39.990 --> 00:02:41.830
You might wanna put that at the end.

58
00:02:41.830 --> 00:02:45.592
So I think it's really more of how much
space you have and how much you wanna say.

59
00:02:45.592 --> 00:02:50.050
>> Right, right, right,
because there's like a book that I enjoy.

60
00:02:50.050 --> 00:02:53.630
It's been updated, my gosh,
like every five years, it gets updated.

61
00:02:53.630 --> 00:02:55.520
And they always include
with the very beginning,

62
00:02:55.520 --> 00:03:00.040
this is the version number
ten of such-and-such a book.

63
00:03:00.040 --> 00:03:02.659
So that would be our footnote?

64
00:03:02.659 --> 00:03:06.480
>> Yeah, I mean, it's really more of like
they're really wanting to put any more

65
00:03:06.480 --> 00:03:09.715
information that they don't really
feel fits in that paragraph.

66
00:03:09.715 --> 00:03:11.296
>> Okay.
>> Making that note of like,

67
00:03:11.296 --> 00:03:15.712
in this addition, we've decided to
change the way we say tomato, tomato,

68
00:03:15.712 --> 00:03:20.059
because that's just what we're going
with because that's the way people

69
00:03:20.059 --> 00:03:21.450
are talking nowadays.

70
00:03:21.450 --> 00:03:22.101
>> They're now calling it to-mu-to.

71
00:03:22.101 --> 00:03:25.050
>> [LAUGH] I like to-mu-to.

72
00:03:25.050 --> 00:03:25.760
>> Tomutoes.

73
00:03:25.760 --> 00:03:27.071
>> Yes, ooples and banoonoos.

74
00:03:27.071 --> 00:03:30.125
>> [SOUND]
>> [LAUGH] It's bringing me back to

75
00:03:30.125 --> 00:03:31.156
my camp songs still, so.

76
00:03:31.156 --> 00:03:32.938
>> Uh-oh,
we're gonna have to hear that one day.

77
00:03:32.938 --> 00:03:34.080
>> I know, right?

78
00:03:34.080 --> 00:03:36.335
[LAUGH] And actually,
I just went ahead and

79
00:03:36.335 --> 00:03:39.306
threw up a website here that
I do have in the show notes.

80
00:03:39.306 --> 00:03:42.150
Looking through,
just kinda double checking.

81
00:03:42.150 --> 00:03:45.106
Hey, cuz it's been awhile
since I've written a report or

82
00:03:45.106 --> 00:03:46.927
anything that I needed footnotes.

83
00:03:46.927 --> 00:03:49.440
So I was like, when do you use them?

84

When, I think it's in reference to tea.

don't forget the biscuits.

more tea moved down.

539
00:27:26.050 --> 00:27:28.700
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, so
I think that that covers pretty much

00:27:28.700 --> 00:27:31.894

541
00:27:31.894 --> 00:27:34.630
Biggest thing,
don't get confused [LAUGH] about end and

542
00:27:34.630 --> 00:27:38.130
foots and read the dialog box and
really think of where you're going.

543
00:27:38.130 --> 00:27:41.690
But the nice thing is hey, I have

544
00:27:41.690 --> 00:27:43.040
I can always switch it back.

545

And just like when anything that

546

547
00:27:51.380 --> 00:27:54.510
it's always good to do a File > Save As,

548
00:27:54.510 --> 00:27:59.040
get a clean copy before you start
doing some of these major changes.

549
00:27:59.040 --> 00:28:02.895
Footnotes and end notes
are pretty safe but just in case,

550
00:28:02.895 --> 00:28:05.950
always have backup, backup, backup.

551
00:28:05.950 --> 00:28:08.270
>> Wonderful, well,
great job as usual, Vonne.

552
00:28:08.270 --> 00:28:13.160
Long documents, Microsoft Word 2016
expert and this has been Footnotes and

553
00:28:13.160 --> 00:28:15.110
Endnotes, thank you for watching.

554
00:28:15.110 --> 00:28:18.580

an Office Pro is always learning.

555
00:28:18.580 --> 00:28:19.380

556
00:28:19.380 --> 00:28:20.160
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

557
00:28:20.160 --> 00:28:28.846
>> And we shall see you again I hope soon,
bye bye.

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Zach demonstrate adding captions to graphical elements. They cover how to create custom labels, how to insert or delete captions that should automatically update (and how to force them to update when it doesnt auto update), and ultimately generate a table of figures.
episodes.title: Captions and Table of Figures

And then the automatic numbering and

I said no no I gotta make

00:22:05.180 --> 00:22:07.230
Cursor's in the right place that I want.

446
00:22:07.230 --> 00:22:12.043
I'll insert my table of figures and
then change the label to table,

447
00:22:12.043 --> 00:22:16.771
and now I have my Table-of-Tables,
and I can do the same thing for

448
00:22:16.771 --> 00:22:19.150
my figures and so on and so forth.

449
00:22:19.150 --> 00:22:22.964
And this is where,
if you did need to change some things,

450
00:22:22.964 --> 00:22:26.697
maybe I took one out,
we'll take out the white rabbit,

451
00:22:26.697 --> 00:22:30.281
maybe I've taken out
the whole picture altogether.

452
00:22:30.281 --> 00:22:33.450
So I've just deleted,
I selected both of those items.

453
00:22:33.450 --> 00:22:37.270
I'm gonna do my Ctrl+A and
force my update.

454
00:22:37.270 --> 00:22:39.670
We will update the fields.

455
00:22:39.670 --> 00:22:43.250
Now this is where I do, I wanna update
every, I would update everything because

456
00:22:43.250 --> 00:22:46.043
you're also going to be updating
your table at the same time.

457
00:22:46.043 --> 00:22:50.407
Because I did that Ctrl+A.

458
00:22:50.407 --> 00:22:52.272
So now it's taken that out.

459
00:22:52.272 --> 00:22:57.031
But it still says, see it says image 2,
3, 4 So let's force that back over.

460
00:22:57.031 --> 00:23:03.440
Let's go into our Print Preview and then
it should, let's update one more time.

461
00:23:03.440 --> 00:23:07.020
We will update our fields and
we'll update the entire table.

462
00:23:08.242 --> 00:23:09.160
There you go.

463
00:23:09.160 --> 00:23:10.140
It just switched.

464
00:23:10.140 --> 00:23:11.770
I did that twice because
it was updating everything.

465
00:23:11.770 --> 00:23:15.930
But again, due to that force, so
if you change something in your document,

466
00:23:15.930 --> 00:23:20.090
make sure you come back and update your
table of figures, just like you would

467
00:23:20.090 --> 00:23:24.121
updating your table of contents, or
your index, or anything like that.

468
00:23:24.121 --> 00:23:26.701
>> Vonne.
Can you have a Table-of-Table's table?

469
00:23:26.701 --> 00:23:29.680
>> [LAUGH] The department
of redundancy department?

470
00:23:29.680 --> 00:23:31.960
Yeah.
[LAUGH] >> [LAUGH] We'll get back to that.

471
00:23:31.960 --> 00:23:35.880
>> Yeah, so it's all about pulling
from the label of the caption.

472
00:23:35.880 --> 00:23:38.390
So you can have a table of whatever.

473
00:23:38.390 --> 00:23:38.940
>> Whatever.

474
00:23:38.940 --> 00:23:40.582
>> A table of hullabaloo, right?

475
00:23:40.582 --> 00:23:42.680
>> Wonderful.
>> So you can pull all that out.

476
00:23:42.680 --> 00:23:46.920
So that I believe, covers everything
that I wanted to do with captions.

477
00:23:46.920 --> 00:23:51.730
Again, biggest thing is just try to get
that document in that final countdown,

478
00:23:51.730 --> 00:23:56.120
and then go ahead and add these different
elements and use that little trick.

479
00:23:56.120 --> 00:24:00.160
It should save you a lot of heartache
of why it's not wanting to play nicely.

480
00:24:00.160 --> 00:24:02.432
>> Well, excellent job as usual, Vonne.

481
00:24:02.432 --> 00:24:06.754
And his belong documents,
captions and table of figures,

482
00:24:06.754 --> 00:24:09.442
Microsoft Word, 2016 expert.

483
00:24:09.442 --> 00:24:11.050
There, that's a mouth full.

484
00:24:11.050 --> 00:24:15.420
And there's a whole bunch of content
in this library or in this series.

485
00:24:15.420 --> 00:24:16.700
So, make sure watch all the videos.

486
00:24:16.700 --> 00:24:17.740
You'll be very glad that you did.

487
00:24:18.990 --> 00:24:20.810
And thank you for watching Office Pro.TV.

488
00:24:20.810 --> 00:24:23.160
Remember, a good office
pro is always learning.

489
00:24:23.160 --> 00:24:23.980
I'm Zac Memmos.

490
00:24:23.980 --> 00:24:24.740
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

491
00:24:24.740 --> 00:24:26.652
>> And we will see you very soon.

492
00:24:26.652 --> 00:24:32.601
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Vonne and Zach demonstrate how to create a master document and use the Outlining tab on the Ribbon. They show how to add, collapse and expand, and unlink subdocuments. They also discuss the importance of using consistent headings.
episodes.title: Master Document
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.680
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.680 --> 00:00:06.948
Hello and thank you for

3
00:00:06.948 --> 00:00:10.433
watching Office ProTV,
helping you learn where ever you go.

4
00:00:10.433 --> 00:00:15.141
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with Microsoft Word 2016

5
00:00:15.141 --> 00:00:16.793
expert long documents.

6
00:00:16.793 --> 00:00:21.162
And we are going to learn right
now what the master document

7
00:00:21.162 --> 00:00:23.311
master document is all about.

8
00:00:23.311 --> 00:00:25.540
Vonne Smith's got the information for
us right here.

9
00:00:25.540 --> 00:00:28.681
>> Yes thank you,
we are going to master those documents and

10
00:00:28.681 --> 00:00:30.459
put them all into one document.

11
00:00:30.459 --> 00:00:32.650
We're gonna make sure-
>> It becomes a master document.

12
00:00:32.650 --> 00:00:35.216
>> Yes, yes and
they will be controlled, and

13
00:00:35.216 --> 00:00:39.271
we are the masters of the universe and-
>> She has the power..

14
00:00:39.271 --> 00:00:42.499
>> Yes, [LAUGH] I love that.

15
00:00:42.499 --> 00:00:45.009
So yes, what is a master document?

16
00:00:45.009 --> 00:00:46.574
I guess we should start there.

17
00:00:46.574 --> 00:00:49.790
So it is, it's the master document.

18
00:00:49.790 --> 00:00:53.215
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's the place that you have

19
00:00:53.215 --> 00:00:58.150
as a single file but
connections to other files.

20
00:00:58.150 --> 00:01:00.950
So this is even more
than just linked objects,

21
00:01:00.950 --> 00:01:04.390
cuz we've talked about linked
objects in some other shows and

22
00:01:04.390 --> 00:01:08.650
episodes where we connected
an Excel spreadsheet into Word.

23
00:01:08.650 --> 00:01:12.550
So if you made changes in Excel,
then it would go ahead and populate and

24
00:01:12.550 --> 00:01:14.930
show in your Word document.

25
00:01:14.930 --> 00:01:17.320
But, the thing was, if you changed any

26
00:01:18.610 --> 00:01:22.820
of the information into that linked
object in Word, it didn't go backwards.

27
00:01:22.820 --> 00:01:25.820
Okay, it was just kind of
a one-way communication street.

28
00:01:25.820 --> 00:01:29.420
In this sense,
when you're creating a master document

29
00:01:29.420 --> 00:01:33.520
you are creating what are known
as sub-documents in that.

30
00:01:33.520 --> 00:01:38.035
And then, those documents are from other
places, and it's a two-way communication.

31
00:01:38.035 --> 00:01:42.750
So if you update the sub-document,
it will update in the master document.

32
00:01:42.750 --> 00:01:46.960
But if you change that in the master
document, it updates here too.

33
00:01:46.960 --> 00:01:49.180
So they're totally connected.

34
00:01:49.180 --> 00:01:51.210
And this is, where would you use this?

35
00:01:51.210 --> 00:01:55.790
Why would I use a master
document with sub documents.

36
00:01:55.790 --> 00:01:56.670
Say you're writing a book.

37
00:01:56.670 --> 00:01:59.110
We've talked about these long documents.

38
00:01:59.110 --> 00:02:02.188
Well instead of having the entire
book in one Word file,

39
00:02:02.188 --> 00:02:04.750
you could have chapter
one as a separate file.

40
00:02:04.750 --> 00:02:09.668
Chapter two, chapter three,
chapter four, chapter five, so

41
00:02:09.668 --> 00:02:12.684
you can work on them in smaller chunks.

42
00:02:12.684 --> 00:02:13.193
And hey,

43
00:02:13.193 --> 00:02:17.470
say if you're doing this in collaboration
with other people with your office.

44
00:02:17.470 --> 00:02:18.229
So maybe you're not even doing chapters.

45
00:02:18.229 --> 00:02:22.475
Maybe it's an annual report and I'm in
charge of the marketing department and

46
00:02:22.475 --> 00:02:25.307
you're in charge of
the advertising department and

47
00:02:25.307 --> 00:02:27.710
somebody else is in
charge of the other one.

48
00:02:27.710 --> 00:02:32.195
So they all have their own pieces of
the whole report that we have to do.

49
00:02:32.195 --> 00:02:36.711
But I'm just gonna assign you to just go
ahead and do the stuff in the advertising.

50
00:02:36.711 --> 00:02:41.493
And then send me the file and
then I will compile them all together into

51
00:02:41.493 --> 00:02:45.790
one master document and
be able to kinda connect it all there.

52
00:02:45.790 --> 00:02:48.170
So it's a nice way to kinda
break up a bigger project.

53
00:02:48.170 --> 00:02:49.650
>> It's also, isn't it,

54
00:02:49.650 --> 00:02:52.875
another way of having a backup of a backup
of a backup if you think about it.

55
00:02:52.875 --> 00:02:54.100
>> [LAUGH] Somewhat.

56
00:02:54.100 --> 00:02:54.710
>> Yeah.

57
00:02:54.710 --> 00:02:58.779
>> In this sense though,
I would say make a backup of that backup.

58
00:02:58.779 --> 00:03:01.961
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because it is connected.

59
00:03:01.961 --> 00:03:03.066
>> Okay, right, that's right.

60
00:03:03.066 --> 00:03:04.022
>> So yeah.

61
00:03:04.022 --> 00:03:05.286
>> Okay, all right.
>> That's where it's not

62
00:03:05.286 --> 00:03:06.302
a two way communicate.

63
00:03:06.302 --> 00:03:08.283
It's not a one way communication
it's that two way.

64
00:03:08.283 --> 00:03:12.513
In that sense I would say,
well if they gave it to me and

65
00:03:12.513 --> 00:03:15.808
emailed it to me, I had it on my computer.

66
00:03:15.808 --> 00:03:20.010
Anything that I do on my connections
to those files is gonna be from me and

67
00:03:20.010 --> 00:03:25.050
I don't have any connections to your
particular document on your computer.

68
00:03:25.050 --> 00:03:26.980
But, take that one step further.

69
00:03:26.980 --> 00:03:31.200
What if I had everything on
a shared network drive and

70
00:03:31.200 --> 00:03:33.360
then everybody has access to it.

71
00:03:33.360 --> 00:03:37.800
And in my master document I'm using the
one that you created, but you go in and

72
00:03:37.800 --> 00:03:41.780
start changing your document but
I've connected into the master,

73
00:03:41.780 --> 00:03:42.870
then it's gonna change there.

74
00:03:42.870 --> 00:03:43.840
>> It's gonna change everything.

75
00:03:43.840 --> 00:03:47.400
>> Yeah, so you do need to be careful
about all of the connections and

76
00:03:47.400 --> 00:03:50.010
the links and who has access to them.

77
00:03:50.010 --> 00:03:54.470
And if you're done, there is an important
step there if you can create a link,

78
00:03:54.470 --> 00:03:55.740
you can also break a link.

79
00:03:55.740 --> 00:03:57.924
So then I say let's break it and

80
00:03:57.924 --> 00:04:02.462
make this master document not
have any connection to that file.

81
00:04:02.462 --> 00:04:04.936
So that way the master stays intact and

82
00:04:04.936 --> 00:04:09.422
any changes that you do in the sub
documents won't change anymore and

83
00:04:09.422 --> 00:04:13.074
it just becomes a big document
with a lot of text in it,.

84
00:04:13.074 --> 00:04:15.239
You just got it from a different place and

85
00:04:15.239 --> 00:04:18.610
then you broke that connection
when you're ready to be done.

86
00:04:18.610 --> 00:04:20.490
>> It's always better
to be safe than sorry.

87
00:04:20.490 --> 00:04:21.698
>> Definitely [LAUGH].

88
00:04:21.698 --> 00:04:22.699
>> Yeah.

89
00:04:22.699 --> 00:04:26.690
>> So we're gonna start by
showing a couple examples.

90
00:04:26.690 --> 00:04:27.690
>> So pretty.

91
00:04:27.690 --> 00:04:28.540
>> Isn't that nice?

92
00:04:28.540 --> 00:04:30.650
It's so calm and relaxing.

93
00:04:30.650 --> 00:04:33.030
It's a timber lake.

94
00:04:33.030 --> 00:04:34.160
>> I love it.

95
00:04:34.160 --> 00:04:34.710
>> Did you see that?

96
00:04:34.710 --> 00:04:35.930
>> Timber, lake.

97
00:04:35.930 --> 00:04:40.605
Justin Timberlake, yeah,
I did all of this on purpose.

98
00:04:40.605 --> 00:04:42.470
[LAUGH] There was thought behind it.

99
00:04:42.470 --> 00:04:45.530
Sometimes I won't have a lot of thought
behind things but in this one I did.

100
00:04:45.530 --> 00:04:48.200
>> And Justin, if you're watching I worked
with you when you were 13 years old in

101
00:04:48.200 --> 00:04:49.400
the MIckey Mouse Club.

102
00:04:49.400 --> 00:04:52.540
Just remember, Zach,
Zach from Disney MGM Studios.

103
00:04:52.540 --> 00:04:53.985
Okay, sorry, go ahead.

104
00:04:53.985 --> 00:04:55.570
>> [LAUGH] I'm so jealous.

105
00:04:55.570 --> 00:04:59.885
Okay, so we have our sub documents
here of down the rabbit hole.

106
00:04:59.885 --> 00:05:04.601
This is just a part of the big document
that we've been working on throughout

107
00:05:04.601 --> 00:05:05.540
these shows.

108
00:05:05.540 --> 00:05:10.159
And so I have down the rabbit hole and
I have it formatted and

109
00:05:10.159 --> 00:05:13.184
there is a section break right there.

110
00:05:13.184 --> 00:05:18.873
Okay, so I just want to point out, there
is a section break in this sub document.

111
00:05:18.873 --> 00:05:21.860
And all the styles that we're using.

112
00:05:21.860 --> 00:05:25.430
That's another thing that if
you start using sub documents,

113
00:05:25.430 --> 00:05:30.208
you kinda wanna try to plan
a little bit ahead and try to keep

114
00:05:30.208 --> 00:05:34.975
a lot of the same formatting and
make sure you're using the same headings.

115
00:05:34.975 --> 00:05:38.258
And try to stay consistent across it
because if you do, it's going to make your

116
00:05:38.258 --> 00:05:41.074
life a lot easier when you bring
it back into that master document.

117
00:05:41.074 --> 00:05:43.553
Because while it will go ahead and

118
00:05:43.553 --> 00:05:48.610
take on the master stylistically
you might have some small issues.

119
00:05:48.610 --> 00:05:53.420
So try to stay as consistent as
possible to avoid more headaches at

120
00:05:53.420 --> 00:05:56.810
the end when you bringing them
all into that master document.

121
00:05:56.810 --> 00:05:58.190
>> Better be safe than sorry.

122
00:05:58.190 --> 00:05:59.400
>> Definitely, yes.

123
00:05:59.400 --> 00:06:02.630
And try to keep all of
this stuff together.

124
00:06:02.630 --> 00:06:05.630
Same thing, you can probably
the idea here with the nights.

125
00:06:05.630 --> 00:06:10.270
I do not have a section break
at the end of the nights.

126
00:06:10.270 --> 00:06:13.333
I'm also just reminding myself, cuz I know
some of them I took some of them out,

127
00:06:13.333 --> 00:06:15.001
some of them I didn't so we'll make sure.

128
00:06:15.001 --> 00:06:16.407
So here's our queen of hearts.

129
00:06:16.407 --> 00:06:18.072
Scroll on down.

130
00:06:18.072 --> 00:06:22.900
Yes, this has a section break and
this is a next page section break.

131
00:06:22.900 --> 00:06:26.723
So when I put them all together,
all of this is going to come in so

132
00:06:26.723 --> 00:06:31.070
we're gonna have the down the rabbit hole,
section break, new page.

133
00:06:31.070 --> 00:06:33.820
Same thing with the queen of hearts,
section break and

134
00:06:33.820 --> 00:06:36.330
then the knights is what
the last part of it.

135
00:06:36.330 --> 00:06:38.790
So that would be like the end chapter,
see what I'm saying, and

136
00:06:38.790 --> 00:06:41.850
then we don't need
a page break from there.

137
00:06:41.850 --> 00:06:47.470
So you can see all the different pieces
of my doc, my chapters as you will.

138
00:06:47.470 --> 00:06:50.160
My master document,
there's nothing in here.

139
00:06:50.160 --> 00:06:52.150
It just has one Alice-in-Wonderland.

140
00:06:52.150 --> 00:06:53.400
I don't have any other text in here.

141
00:06:53.400 --> 00:06:55.384
So you could be starting
this from a file new.

142
00:06:55.384 --> 00:06:58.693
You don't have to name it master document.

143
00:06:58.693 --> 00:07:01.917
So don't think like I have
to keep it that name.

144
00:07:01.917 --> 00:07:03.704
No, I just named that for this example.

145
00:07:03.704 --> 00:07:05.025
>> Can you name it She-Ra?

146
00:07:05.025 --> 00:07:07.259
>> [LAUGH] Yes, we totally could.

147
00:07:07.259 --> 00:07:08.251
>> Good, good.

148
00:07:08.251 --> 00:07:12.465
>> [LAUGH] And so we can name it anything
we want and I'm gonna enter cause I'm

149
00:07:12.465 --> 00:07:16.500
thinking like I'm gonna type all
the rest of that information.

150
00:07:16.500 --> 00:07:19.470
So now I'm just gonna start
putting in those sub documents.

151
00:07:21.010 --> 00:07:23.860
One other kind of gotta
have this type thing.

152
00:07:23.860 --> 00:07:25.280
I mentioned styles.

153
00:07:25.280 --> 00:07:30.055
I should take that one step further in
what you really need to have when you're

154
00:07:30.055 --> 00:07:32.487
starting to create master documents.

155
00:07:32.487 --> 00:07:34.344
You do need to use heading levels.

156
00:07:34.344 --> 00:07:38.635
You have to have heading levels cuz
otherwise it doesn't really kind of

157
00:07:38.635 --> 00:07:41.710
understand what's going
on in your documents.

158
00:07:41.710 --> 00:07:43.890
So that's like a must.

159
00:07:43.890 --> 00:07:45.841
You can format it however you want, but

160
00:07:45.841 --> 00:07:49.924
definitely keep all those headings because
how we're going to get into our master

161
00:07:49.924 --> 00:07:52.844
document is we're going to
have to go into outlying view.

162
00:07:52.844 --> 00:07:58.075
In an outlying view, in Word, it's always,
it relies on those headings and

163
00:07:58.075 --> 00:08:03.642
those structural tabs, sorry, structural
elements I went back to my HTML days.

164
00:08:03.642 --> 00:08:07.722
[LAUGH] This is Heading 1,
Heading 2, Heading 3,

165
00:08:07.722 --> 00:08:12.200
are organized where the levels
are in your document.

166
00:08:12.200 --> 00:08:14.470
So you do need to have those.

167
00:08:14.470 --> 00:08:16.580
How do I get over into the Outline View?

168
00:08:16.580 --> 00:08:20.120
Well, you go over to the view tab,
and you go over to outline.

169
00:08:20.120 --> 00:08:23.970
And, when you go into outline,
it takes you into this world,

170
00:08:23.970 --> 00:08:29.450
that has these little dots and pluses and
minuses, indicating where those different

171
00:08:29.450 --> 00:08:33.640
changes of headings, and the dots are
indicated of where your paragraphs are.

172
00:08:33.640 --> 00:08:37.010
So I have my cursor here.

173
00:08:37.010 --> 00:08:42.230
I want to then start compiling in those
sub-documents in my master documents.

174
00:08:42.230 --> 00:08:44.310
So now I'm in to it.

175
00:08:44.310 --> 00:08:47.050
You're gonna click
the Show Document button and

176
00:08:47.050 --> 00:08:50.970
then the Show Document button brings
you into this create and insert.

177
00:08:50.970 --> 00:08:54.220
And you can see there's Merge, Split,
Unlink, those different things we're

178
00:08:54.220 --> 00:08:58.950
going to be doing,
with inserting in those sub-documents.

179
00:08:58.950 --> 00:09:02.364
So we'll click the Insert,
and come into here.

180
00:09:02.364 --> 00:09:06.420
We'll go to the desktop, because that's
where I have these particular files, and

181
00:09:06.420 --> 00:09:08.875
because I was gonna be
messing around with them, so

182
00:09:08.875 --> 00:09:11.350
I didn't wanna change
the original access files.

183
00:09:11.350 --> 00:09:14.570
Talking about backups in a sense,
I have those in that folder for

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne show you how to track changes made to documents in Word 2016. Here you will specifically learn how to enable/disable tracking, add comments, make changes, and how to modify display preferences. They demonstrate how to review tracked changes by accepting or rejecting changes as well as deleting comments. They also show how to lock tracking so collaborators cannot turn them off.
episodes.title: Track Changes

00:21:24.920 --> 00:21:29.560
simple or all and then theres
the original of what did it start with,

415
00:21:29.560 --> 00:21:32.970
okay, this is all the cool things
about having those tracked changes.

416
00:21:32.970 --> 00:21:35.210
Cuz the original is still there.

417
00:21:35.210 --> 00:21:39.180
We haven't done a hard commit
to any of these changes.

418
00:21:39.180 --> 00:21:41.850
Cuz right now it's just being tracked and

419
00:21:41.850 --> 00:21:44.530
kinda keeping in that
memory if you wanna say.

420
00:21:44.530 --> 00:21:47.230
And then I can decide whether or
not I want to do that or not.

421
00:21:47.230 --> 00:21:50.250
So all markup is good to
make sure you see everything

422
00:21:50.250 --> 00:21:51.680
over there on the right hand side.

423
00:21:52.720 --> 00:21:56.970
The other button right below it is
what am I showing as my markup?

424
00:21:56.970 --> 00:22:00.310
And you can see the check boxes
here of I'm showing comments,

425
00:22:00.310 --> 00:22:02.660
I'm showing any ink
notations if you have those.

426
00:22:02.660 --> 00:22:04.900
We don't have that right now.

427
00:22:04.900 --> 00:22:07.060
Insertions and deletions, we did that.

428
00:22:07.060 --> 00:22:09.420
The formatting, and then the balloons.

429
00:22:09.420 --> 00:22:13.630
And that's why I had to correct myself
with saying it's all showing in line,

430
00:22:13.630 --> 00:22:17.180
because it's me in like a general
sense of the word in line.

431
00:22:17.180 --> 00:22:20.440
It's like yeah,
it's right where the edits happened.

432
00:22:20.440 --> 00:22:25.300
But technically, see,
if I still show revisions in line,

433
00:22:25.300 --> 00:22:29.720
then it goes directly in line and
not off to the side.

434
00:22:29.720 --> 00:22:31.950
So just clarifying that.

435
00:22:31.950 --> 00:22:35.050
Within the context of Word
in that particular meaning.

436
00:22:35.050 --> 00:22:36.560
It's kinda like templates.

437
00:22:36.560 --> 00:22:38.090
You throw the word template around, but

438
00:22:38.090 --> 00:22:41.410
it means something kinda
different in Word, so.

439
00:22:41.410 --> 00:22:42.860
We have the balloons, we have that.

440
00:22:42.860 --> 00:22:47.800
Okay, show comments and formatting in
balloons, show all revisions in balloons.

441
00:22:47.800 --> 00:22:50.940
So these are the defaults
that you can see.

442
00:22:50.940 --> 00:22:55.300
And then when we start getting into
multiple reviewers, we'll show that in

443
00:22:55.300 --> 00:23:00.040
the Compare and Combine, you might
combine edits from multiple people.

444
00:23:00.040 --> 00:23:03.210
And this is where you can choose,
hey I only wanna see Joey's, or

445
00:23:03.210 --> 00:23:06.480
only see Lance's, or
me as the owner of this document.

446
00:23:06.480 --> 00:23:09.350
I don't need to see
things I made changes to.

447
00:23:09.350 --> 00:23:11.600
I only wanna see what Joey did.

448
00:23:11.600 --> 00:23:18.700
So I can turn off Justin and just see
Joey's comments and mark ups that he did.

449
00:23:18.700 --> 00:23:24.000
So this is another drop-down to
just make sure that you're seeing

450
00:23:24.000 --> 00:23:26.940
what you think you're supposed to be
seeing, and what's actually there.

451
00:23:28.250 --> 00:23:32.460
And then the revealing pane, this is if
you put it off to the side or the bottom.

452
00:23:32.460 --> 00:23:36.610
If I go with vertical,
it's off over here in a vertical fashion

453
00:23:36.610 --> 00:23:40.280
versus putting it into a horizontal and
it goes underneath.

454
00:23:40.280 --> 00:23:44.540
I usually choose off to the side cuz then
you can actually change the two pointed

455
00:23:44.540 --> 00:23:49.790
white arrows how wide this panel is,
and this is going through and

456
00:23:49.790 --> 00:23:54.880
showing you everything, all the revisions
that have been done in this document.

457
00:23:54.880 --> 00:23:58.790
And you see if you click on them,
it's actually going to go to the specific

458
00:23:58.790 --> 00:24:02.870
places that that particular
revision is done in the document.

459
00:24:02.870 --> 00:24:05.906
Really good if you have a really
long document across multiple pages.

460
00:24:05.906 --> 00:24:08.866
I kept it simple by just keeping one,
so we can see it all.

461
00:24:08.866 --> 00:24:13.463
But that's really nice to be able to see
the revisions in this pane in a list

462
00:24:13.463 --> 00:24:15.031
format if you wanna say.

463
00:24:15.031 --> 00:24:17.303
I'm gonna close that for now and

464
00:24:17.303 --> 00:24:22.194
zoom out just a little bit if I get
the right keys selected, perfect.

465
00:24:22.194 --> 00:24:28.206
So as the owner I can go through and
accept or reject changes.

466
00:24:28.206 --> 00:24:32.857
So I'll start at the beginning, I'll put
my cursor up at the top if we go up to

467
00:24:32.857 --> 00:24:37.220
these buttons we can go to the next
change, the next track change well,

468
00:24:37.220 --> 00:24:41.900
that was mine and notice it is kinda
highlighting over my comment as Justin.

469
00:24:41.900 --> 00:24:46.310
And then the next one is putting
the cursor you can see it right there,

470
00:24:46.310 --> 00:24:49.429
it's following the next
particular revision,

471
00:24:49.429 --> 00:24:52.413
that Joey went ahead and
answered my comment.

472
00:24:52.413 --> 00:24:56.391
Now this is just moving through here,
now do I really need to accept or

473
00:24:56.391 --> 00:24:58.392
reject that particular comment?

474
00:24:58.392 --> 00:25:03.191
Cuz it's not an edit it's just a comment
so, I'm just gonna pass over that for

475
00:25:03.191 --> 00:25:08.151
now come back around to how I can get rid
of the comments after I'm done with this.

476
00:25:08.151 --> 00:25:13.809
So the next one is down, down, down that
might be a decent thing it's like, okay I

477
00:25:13.809 --> 00:25:19.314
maybe redundant but with department,
Redundancy Department, redundancy.

478
00:25:19.314 --> 00:25:21.903
>> [LAUGH
>> I totally mess that one up, yeah.

479
00:25:21.903 --> 00:25:24.086
>> Yeah.
>> The one we're doing last week.

480
00:25:24.086 --> 00:25:25.670
>> The redundant,
Department of Redundancy?

481
00:25:25.670 --> 00:25:26.625
>> Yes, that's it, yes.

482
00:25:26.625 --> 00:25:30.807
So it's like we don't really
need to have that many down so,

483
00:25:30.807 --> 00:25:36.140
I will accept this change so, I click
accept and it's like, yep there we go.

484
00:25:36.140 --> 00:25:41.083
Then the next one, so let's go with next,
Diana was the cat, well not everybody

485
00:25:41.083 --> 00:25:45.823
knows that Diana was the cat, maybe they
think Diana is the wife or whatever.

486
00:25:45.823 --> 00:25:46.895
>> Stupid Joey.

487
00:25:46.895 --> 00:25:49.520
>> Come on Joey don't assume,
you know what happens.

488
00:25:49.520 --> 00:25:52.246
>> That's right, hypothesize.

489
00:25:52.246 --> 00:25:57.352
So I will reject this change and you can
see that the text goes right back into

490
00:25:57.352 --> 00:26:02.890
the document cuz he had deleted it, but
I'm saying no, and so it keeps in there.

491
00:26:02.890 --> 00:26:05.926
Cuz it still has got all
that original content, and

492
00:26:05.926 --> 00:26:07.839
then we just keep on going down.

493
00:26:07.839 --> 00:26:11.906
Now the other way instead of clicking
these next and previous buttons,

494
00:26:11.906 --> 00:26:14.770
if I wanted to come into here,
is this repeating?

495
00:26:14.770 --> 00:26:18.277
And I could, if I was going back and
forth with him, I might say like,

496
00:26:18.277 --> 00:26:22.455
well yeah it's repeating that's just
because I'm getting placeholder text for

497
00:26:22.455 --> 00:26:24.415
these episodes for demonstrations.

498
00:26:24.415 --> 00:26:29.179
So you can right-click on anything that's
over there on the right hand side,

499
00:26:29.179 --> 00:26:31.910
in this case, this is a comment.

500
00:26:31.910 --> 00:26:34.598
So it's not an accept or reject,

501
00:26:34.598 --> 00:26:39.114
it is either delete the comment or
reply to the comment.

502
00:26:39.114 --> 00:26:42.340
And at this point sentence is just a note,
I was like no,

503
00:26:42.340 --> 00:26:46.750
no we're good Joey, thanks for
catching that, but that doesn't matter.

504
00:26:46.750 --> 00:26:51.742
So I'm just gonna delete it and I can
keep on going so, right clicking on your

505
00:26:51.742 --> 00:26:56.510
comments or any of your edits is just
another comment that I will delete.

506
00:26:56.510 --> 00:26:59.987
And then I can see that Joey
deleted all of this text and

507
00:26:59.987 --> 00:27:03.401
I realized yep that was
supposed to be deleted.

508
00:27:03.401 --> 00:27:08.322
And notice and it's a little bit behind
my head as well, you can see that when I

509
00:27:08.322 --> 00:27:13.170
right-click on this I can accept or
reject right from the particular edit in

510
00:27:13.170 --> 00:27:18.190
that side right hand, I don't have to do
from the buttons up top on the ribbon.

511
00:27:18.190 --> 00:27:22.623
So whichever way you feel more
comfortable, I will accept that change and

512
00:27:22.623 --> 00:27:27.125
I will not accept this one because I do
not want that to be its own heading so,

513
00:27:27.125 --> 00:27:28.223
I will reject it.

514
00:27:28.223 --> 00:27:34.030
And it's getting rather tired instead of
sleepy, all right, we'll accept that one.

515
00:27:34.030 --> 00:27:38.196
And now, there's one more you can
see that I've added text here so,

516
00:27:38.196 --> 00:27:42.099
if I didn't want that to happen
you can right-click here as well.

517
00:27:42.099 --> 00:27:46.562
Now this is one that didn't come off to
the side because added text is going to

518
00:27:46.562 --> 00:27:50.428
be like in the document itself so,
I think all of that looks good.

519
00:27:50.428 --> 00:27:54.822
So I've gone through, let me delete
this cuz I don't need that, perfect.

520
00:27:54.822 --> 00:27:59.145
So I have used the track changes
to collaborate with a team member,

521
00:27:59.145 --> 00:28:02.463
I've gotten all the comments,
I've accepted and

522
00:28:02.463 --> 00:28:05.570
rejected this is going
to be my final document.

523
00:28:05.570 --> 00:28:09.812
Always good to do a file save
as just to make sure so,

524
00:28:09.812 --> 00:28:13.867
I could say track changes
final I will save this.

525
00:28:13.867 --> 00:28:18.702
And now this is where I'm done,
I don't want to track any more changes,

526
00:28:18.702 --> 00:28:21.808
you should really turn
the track changes off.

527
00:28:21.808 --> 00:28:24.791
>> [LAUGH]
>> Looks like I forgot to turn them on,

528
00:28:24.791 --> 00:28:27.581
I don't wanna turn them off but
I did lock them so,

529
00:28:27.581 --> 00:28:32.046
if I turn that off that will be good,
and that was the other document, right?

530
00:28:32.046 --> 00:28:33.029
>> Right.

531
00:28:33.029 --> 00:28:37.401
>> Okay, staying on track but
if you had locked it you would need to put

532
00:28:37.401 --> 00:28:42.396
in that password, and then once it is
unlocked you just turn the button off,

533
00:28:42.396 --> 00:28:45.010
and then we save that and there we go.

534
00:28:45.010 --> 00:28:49.912
So track changes its super cool, it's
a great way to not commit to any changes

535
00:28:49.912 --> 00:28:54.739
in that whole reviewing process and
going back and forth, I use this a lot and

536
00:28:54.739 --> 00:28:56.722
it's really, really great.

537
00:28:56.722 --> 00:29:00.778
So hopefully, you can see some reasons
why you would need to use this, and

538
00:29:00.778 --> 00:29:02.160
now you know how to do it.

539
00:29:02.160 --> 00:29:05.063
>> Yvonne, I believe a blind man
could see the benefit of using

540
00:29:05.063 --> 00:29:08.546
the tracking of changes, very cool
tool that they put inside of Word for

541
00:29:08.546 --> 00:29:10.364
us to be able to collaborate better.

542
00:29:10.364 --> 00:29:14.812
And make sure that we don't forget any
reasons that we were doing certain things,

543
00:29:14.812 --> 00:29:15.784
and who did what?

544
00:29:15.784 --> 00:29:19.002
That's also another important thing,
don't forget to turn it off and

545
00:29:19.002 --> 00:29:21.264
on as necessary or
if you need to, even lock it up.

546
00:29:21.264 --> 00:29:24.033
Yvonne, you did a great job
demonstrating this how we can use

547
00:29:24.033 --> 00:29:27.890
this in our environments, hopefully you
guys got a lot out of this episode.

548
00:29:27.890 --> 00:29:30.720
But it does like it is that time for
us to sign off for OfficePro TV,

549
00:29:30.720 --> 00:29:32.319
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

550
00:29:32.319 --> 00:29:33.266
>> And I'm Yvonne Smith.

551
00:29:33.266 --> 00:29:34.174
>> And we'll see you next time.

552
00:29:34.174 --> 00:29:39.925
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne take a look at two separate, yet related functions  compare documents and combine documents. First, they explore using compare documents which allows you to merge two documents together and Word highlights the differences. Next, they show you how to combine tracked edits from multiple documents into a single document.
episodes.title: Compare and Combine Documents
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.205 --> 00:00:06.842
[SOUND]
All right,

2
00:00:06.842 --> 00:00:10.300
greetings everyone and welcome back to
another great episode of OfficePro TV.

3
00:00:10.300 --> 00:00:14.713
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in today's
episode it is continuing on with more in

4
00:00:14.713 --> 00:00:16.867
our Word 2016 expert level series.

5
00:00:16.867 --> 00:00:20.924
And joining us back in the studio The
expert of Word herself, Ms. Vonne Smith.

6
00:00:20.924 --> 00:00:23.434
Vonne, thank you so much for
coming by, how are you today?

7
00:00:23.434 --> 00:00:30.374
>> I'm fantastic, I'm ready to compare and
contrast, comparing and combining.

8
00:00:30.374 --> 00:00:32.367
>> [LAUGH]
>> There's all these words that

9
00:00:32.367 --> 00:00:32.894
start with Cs.

10
00:00:32.894 --> 00:00:34.310
>> Like peanut butter and jelly, right?

11
00:00:34.310 --> 00:00:36.090
It's hard not to say
the two things together.

12
00:00:36.090 --> 00:00:38.360
>> Exactly, I'm like, I can't remember
what we're doing right now, but

13
00:00:38.360 --> 00:00:43.690
we [LAUGH] We are comparing and
combining documents.

14
00:00:43.690 --> 00:00:47.450
It's funny we had this discussion
before we started filming.

15
00:00:47.450 --> 00:00:50.240
Well, I didn't know if I should put and.

16
00:00:50.240 --> 00:00:51.780
And we talked about semantics.

17
00:00:51.780 --> 00:00:54.890
Cuz they're not really
doing the same thing.

18
00:00:54.890 --> 00:00:58.490
They're two separate
functions that you do.

19
00:00:58.490 --> 00:01:02.720
In Word, but sometimes to me,
it's like if you can compare and combine,

20
00:01:02.720 --> 00:01:04.918
they're together but they're not.

21
00:01:04.918 --> 00:01:05.542
>> Right.

22
00:01:05.542 --> 00:01:07.140
>> They're mutually exclusive.

23
00:01:07.140 --> 00:01:10.020
So we kinda started getting
into context and everything.

24
00:01:10.020 --> 00:01:11.409
But we went ahead and put and

25
00:01:11.409 --> 00:01:14.928
in the title to make sure that you
know that this is what we're doing.

26
00:01:14.928 --> 00:01:18.755
Because it's one of those,
when you talk about, the words in general,

27
00:01:18.755 --> 00:01:21.288
not talking about the actual
function in word.

28
00:01:21.288 --> 00:01:26.581
If you're going to compare something,
well, you're combining them anyways,

29
00:01:26.581 --> 00:01:30.663
so we're combining, comparing,
contrasting, whatever.

30
00:01:30.663 --> 00:01:32.950
[LAUGH]
>> It's an interesting trickery of

31
00:01:32.950 --> 00:01:33.645
language right now.

32
00:01:33.645 --> 00:01:34.908
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, exactly,

33
00:01:34.908 --> 00:01:37.696
yeah, the English
language is really weird.

34
00:01:37.696 --> 00:01:40.859
And then you thrown in all these
technical stuffs on top of it and take,

35
00:01:40.859 --> 00:01:43.485
we doesn't really mean that
the way we normally think of it

36
00:01:43.485 --> 00:01:45.830
when we're talking about
in the world of word.

37
00:01:45.830 --> 00:01:49.374
>> So your point being, Vonne,
that we are going to compare one thing,

38
00:01:49.374 --> 00:01:52.137
that is one thing that we are going to do,
comparing.

39
00:01:52.137 --> 00:01:55.727
And we are also gonna combine which is
another thing that we're going to do, but

40
00:01:55.727 --> 00:01:58.310
maybe not necessarily
together at the same time.

41
00:01:58.310 --> 00:02:02.320
>> Exactly Daniel, that is a perfect way
to describe what we're gonna be doing.

42
00:02:02.320 --> 00:02:06.430
So in a previous episode,
we had talked about tracking changes.

43
00:02:06.430 --> 00:02:08.700
We went ahead and
turned on the track changes.

44
00:02:08.700 --> 00:02:09.870
Gotta make sure you do that.

45
00:02:09.870 --> 00:02:13.050
And then, you send it off to somebody or
maybe it's just yourself.

46
00:02:13.050 --> 00:02:17.310
And you go through and make your changes
and you can see what was changed.

47
00:02:17.310 --> 00:02:19.670
So that's a good way to track your edits.

48
00:02:19.670 --> 00:02:22.880
Well, what if I forgot to
turn on the track changes?

49
00:02:22.880 --> 00:02:24.830
And I sent my document off to Joey.

50
00:02:24.830 --> 00:02:26.480
Joey went ahead and made his changes.

51
00:02:26.480 --> 00:02:29.580
I get it back and
I'm like I don't know what's different.

52
00:02:29.580 --> 00:02:32.650
And maybe I print it out and
go line by line and read each one.

53
00:02:32.650 --> 00:02:33.600
And then you get really confused.

54
00:02:33.600 --> 00:02:36.520
I don't know, there's just so
many differences.

55
00:02:36.520 --> 00:02:39.303
But I know I started with
this original document.

56
00:02:39.303 --> 00:02:46.090
And then, this is the modified document I
want to compare and see what is different.

57
00:02:46.090 --> 00:02:49.160
And that's exactly what we're going to do.

58
00:02:49.160 --> 00:02:51.510
Now, with combining separate function.

59
00:02:51.510 --> 00:02:56.090
That's where you can combine multiple
edits from multiple authors.

60
00:02:56.090 --> 00:02:59.580
Now, this is one where you
are using track changes.

61
00:02:59.580 --> 00:03:00.960
And let's say that I have two editors.

62
00:03:00.960 --> 00:03:06.380
I have Lance and
I have Joey as both editors,

63
00:03:06.380 --> 00:03:09.750

changes on, had them do their edits,

64
00:03:09.750 --> 00:03:14.020
it comes back to me, Justin,
as the owner of a document.

65
00:03:14.020 --> 00:03:19.270
Well, now I want to combine
all of Lance's edits and

66
00:03:19.270 --> 00:03:24.710

I can see everybody all together.

67
00:03:24.710 --> 00:03:28.063
>> Question, can you edit an edit?

68
00:03:28.063 --> 00:03:31.900
>> [LAUGH] So like you said,
we had two editors right.

69
00:03:31.900 --> 00:03:32.644
You made a change.

70
00:03:32.644 --> 00:03:33.676
You're an editor, I'm an editor.

71
00:03:33.676 --> 00:03:36.090
You make a change I go,
Vonne's wrong there.

72
00:03:36.090 --> 00:03:37.840
And I make a change to your edit.

73
00:03:37.840 --> 00:03:41.570
What does it do with that or
can you even do that?

74
00:03:41.570 --> 00:03:45.220
>> Well, in this sense,
it's not Joey's gonna do the edits,

75
00:03:45.220 --> 00:03:47.010
then pass it on to Lance.

76
00:03:47.010 --> 00:03:49.400
So in this sense,
you sent it out this way.

77
00:03:49.400 --> 00:03:51.966
And so he's doing his edits,
he's doing his edits, and then they're.

78
00:03:51.966 --> 00:03:53.800
>> So they're not really
conflicting with each other.

79
00:03:53.800 --> 00:03:54.720
>> Correct, yes, but

80
00:03:54.720 --> 00:03:57.700
that's where what if they both made the
>> Same edit.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne show you how to collaborate with others to make edits in your documents using OneDrive and other Office 365 account features. They will explain how to invite collaborators, chat in real time, and remove sharing in OneDrive when necessary. They demonstrate using both locally installed Word and Word Online.
episodes.title: Collaborate Online

We do thank you for watching, while we

>> And we'll see you next time.

464

And now, I've restricted the editing.

So you can see now that if I was anyone,

Or I can show all regions and it's going

All of this other spaces,

And I can't, do that.

And notice, right here.

This area, is not letting me,

So that, can really, really helpful.

We go ahead and say, this is what you can

[LAUGH]

But in theory it should, so of course,

Where this can get a little wonky

So if you encounter that you do this and

00:12:22.571 --> 00:12:27.710
we're a network, we're on Office 365 but
It wasn't setting up.

224
00:12:27.710 --> 00:12:31.822
And so, I have seen some things
across multiple message boards

225
00:12:31.822 --> 00:12:36.460
that yeah we've had to go one more
step to make this actually work.

226
00:12:36.460 --> 00:12:40.470
And then I also saw some other post of

227
00:12:40.470 --> 00:12:45.620
different scenarios where it's one of
those like this is a great feature.

228
00:12:45.620 --> 00:12:53.030
And being able to limit areas of your
document with restrictions is fantastic.

229
00:12:53.030 --> 00:12:56.050
But its one of those, I felt when
I'm reading people's scenarios.

230
00:12:56.050 --> 00:12:59.055
Like you're trying to make it do
something its not really supposed to do.

231
00:12:59.055 --> 00:13:01.000
It's like any type of product.

232
00:13:01.000 --> 00:13:04.040
I've always remembered this share point.

233
00:13:04.040 --> 00:13:04.800
Like I have a boss.

234
00:13:04.800 --> 00:13:06.130
He's a great product.

235
00:13:06.130 --> 00:13:08.802
But then they're like-
>> Then they try to use it.

236
00:13:08.802 --> 00:13:10.330
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, or they try to say,

237
00:13:10.330 --> 00:13:14.360
well I wanted to, it's set to do this but
I really want it to do this.

238
00:13:14.360 --> 00:13:14.950
>> Yeah.

239
00:13:14.950 --> 00:13:18.150
>> And you're kinda forcing almost
like a square peg in a round hole and

240
00:13:18.150 --> 00:13:19.580
it doesn't always work.

241
00:13:19.580 --> 00:13:23.860
And I'm not saying that this won't work,
I'm just saying try to just remember.

242
00:13:23.860 --> 00:13:25.855
>> As Justin would say,
your mileage may vary.

243
00:13:25.855 --> 00:13:28.202
>> [LAUGH] I love that, yes.

244
00:13:28.202 --> 00:13:31.923
Just try to keep it within
the context of what it can do.

245
00:13:31.923 --> 00:13:33.894
And if you're going all sorts of crazy.

246
00:13:33.894 --> 00:13:36.290
They're talking about all these forms and
they don't want people to change them.

247
00:13:37.330 --> 00:13:39.550
Word is not necessarily
the best with forms.

248
00:13:39.550 --> 00:13:40.603
It's okay.
It's pretty good, but

249
00:13:40.603 --> 00:13:41.465
you might need a [CROSSTALK].

250
00:13:41.465 --> 00:13:43.230
>> But if you're getting into that level.

251
00:13:43.230 --> 00:13:45.320
Or it's probably not

252
00:13:45.320 --> 00:13:49.880
It's time to move to a more, a product
centered around doing that type of thing.

253
00:13:49.880 --> 00:13:53.100
>> Exactly and a lot of times people they
don't even now what that product this.

254
00:13:53.100 --> 00:13:55.630
And so it's like this but
this is the only product I have.

255
00:13:55.630 --> 00:13:56.640
So, I have to make it work.

256
00:13:56.640 --> 00:13:57.880
So I completely understand all.

257
00:13:57.880 --> 00:14:00.377
>> And kudos to the good people at
Microsoft that say, you know what,

258
00:14:00.377 --> 00:14:03.470
we see that there are some people that
maybe aren't ready to jump into something.

259
00:14:03.470 --> 00:14:07.511
That is more professionally centered
toward this specific thing that they're

260
00:14:07.511 --> 00:14:08.500
trying to do.

261
00:14:08.500 --> 00:14:10.940
So let's try to add some of that
functionality inside of word so

262
00:14:10.940 --> 00:14:12.330
they've already bought a product.

263
00:14:12.330 --> 00:14:14.260
They can use it to some extent.

264
00:14:14.260 --> 00:14:17.580
>> Yeah and they always are expanding
to make other products.

265
00:14:17.580 --> 00:14:19.880
And they were talking about info path and

266
00:14:19.880 --> 00:14:22.870
I know that's a specific product that
does do a little bit more reforms.

267
00:14:22.870 --> 00:14:25.040
They were talking about moving
off into and I'm like wait,

268
00:14:25.040 --> 00:14:26.455
aren't going the wrong way?

269
00:14:26.455 --> 00:14:27.880
[LAUGH] But those are different things.

270
00:14:27.880 --> 00:14:31.420
So I just wanted to kinda put
that little caveat, that little.

271
00:14:31.420 --> 00:14:35.917
If you're going to that individual level
that we're saying in the exceptions,

272
00:14:35.917 --> 00:14:38.440
you might need to contact

273
00:14:38.440 --> 00:14:41.980
To make sure that that does work and
always test it out.

274
00:14:41.980 --> 00:14:46.228
If it's not working, there's always these
little things you find work arounds.

275
00:14:46.228 --> 00:14:49.738
Cuz we do it all the time like, hey, this
is how it will really work even though

276
00:14:49.738 --> 00:14:51.590
instructions tell you to do it this way.

277
00:14:51.590 --> 00:14:56.890
So that's my little
note on this Part Three

278
00:14:56.890 --> 00:15:01.052
of Document Security and
restricting areas with those exemptions.

279
00:15:01.052 --> 00:15:04.250
>> All right, Vonne now that we have
a more well-rounded knowledge base when it

280
00:15:04.250 --> 00:15:05.810
comes to document security.

281
00:15:05.810 --> 00:15:07.250
We're gonna go ahead and
thank you for that.

282
00:15:07.250 --> 00:15:10.670
Because you've really spent some time and

283
00:15:10.670 --> 00:15:13.530
That being said, we appreciate our
audience for joining us as well.

284
00:15:13.530 --> 00:15:15.990
But it is that time for us to sign off.

285
00:15:15.990 --> 00:15:18.420
For Office Pro TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

286
00:15:18.420 --> 00:15:19.420
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

287
00:15:19.420 --> 00:15:20.205
>> We'll see you next time.

288
00:15:20.205 --> 00:15:26.022
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate working with document properties which will help make a document more searchable as well as adding more usable information to a document. This is also known as metadata. They also discuss important features such as inspect a document, check accessibility, and check compatibility.
episodes.title: Document Properties
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.105 --> 00:00:05.817
[MUSIC]

2

All right, greetings, everyone, and

00:00:10.462 --> 00:00:13.770
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,

it's all about Word 2016,

[LAUGH]

>> Yeah, [LAUGH] I know, I'm like,

00:00:39.182 --> 00:00:43.000
[LAUGH] We're gonna talk

19

Where are they?

20
00:00:45.380 --> 00:00:46.850
Why do we use them?

21
00:00:46.850 --> 00:00:49.787
All of the what, where, why, how, when-

22
00:00:49.787 --> 00:00:52.619
>> Who, yeah [LAUGH],
like a missing one [LAUGH].

23
00:00:52.619 --> 00:00:57.903
All right, so the document properties
are things that you add to your files.

24
00:00:57.903 --> 00:01:04.180
It's the hidden information in the back,
what can also be referred to as metadata.

25
00:01:04.180 --> 00:01:06.692
Metadata is the behind the scenes stuff.

26
00:01:06.692 --> 00:01:12.580
Now this is something that I remember from
my coding days of creating web pages.

27
00:01:12.580 --> 00:01:17.236
Where in the head section of your HTML
file, you have a head and a body.

28
00:01:17.236 --> 00:01:20.835
Think about head, your brain,
your body, well, the body.

29
00:01:20.835 --> 00:01:22.165
And then-
>> The thing that does stuff.

30
00:01:22.165 --> 00:01:26.975
>> Yeah, and so in the head section,
you would put in metadata, and

31
00:01:26.975 --> 00:01:32.500
there's an actual tag called meta, and
you could have things like keywords.

32
00:01:32.500 --> 00:01:36.760
So what are different keywords that
I would like to associate with this

33
00:01:36.760 --> 00:01:40.958
particular web page that people would
then maybe type in in a search?

34
00:01:40.958 --> 00:01:43.750
And then they would match, and
then that would bring that up.

35

And so they use it for

36

what's known as search engine optimization
and different things like that.

37
00:01:47.700 --> 00:01:51.570
But as a user,
as somebody coming to the website,

38
00:01:51.570 --> 00:01:55.760
you don't see any of that
information in the background.

39
00:01:55.760 --> 00:02:01.760
But it is used for certain things, like
searching and optimization for web pages.

40
00:02:01.760 --> 00:02:04.930
And you can correlate
that directly into Word.

41
00:02:04.930 --> 00:02:10.570
If I add in information in
the background of this Word file,

42
00:02:10.570 --> 00:02:13.070
it can be used for searching purposes.

43
00:02:13.070 --> 00:02:14.850
I can use just Windows,

44
00:02:14.850 --> 00:02:18.080
just a regular Windows search,
I know I had this document.

45
00:02:18.080 --> 00:02:22.200
And I was talking about fields and
properties.

46
00:02:22.200 --> 00:02:27.010
Well, if I had added that into
a document's tags in that document

47
00:02:27.010 --> 00:02:31.880
properties, it would find that information
and use that and give me the result in

48
00:02:31.880 --> 00:02:36.970
my search based on that extra information,
so that's where it could be useful.

49
00:02:36.970 --> 00:02:41.938
And then sometimes you might be in an
organization that you're almost required,

50
00:02:41.938 --> 00:02:45.903
if you wanna say, to put in those
different types of properties.

51
00:02:45.903 --> 00:02:50.212
So say, I know this was one that I had
somebody working in the legal industry.

52
00:02:50.212 --> 00:02:53.790
And so they said, we had to put all
that stuff, what case it was, and

53
00:02:53.790 --> 00:02:56.350

all these different things.

54
00:02:56.350 --> 00:03:00.310
Because it really mattered in
that type of profession and

55
00:03:00.310 --> 00:03:02.940

56
00:03:02.940 --> 00:03:06.940
And what is all this and then it's
important, but the other thing is, if you

57
00:03:06.940 --> 00:03:11.870

that document, it could be sensitive.

58
00:03:11.870 --> 00:03:14.330
It can be things that you don't
want people to be able to see,

59
00:03:14.330 --> 00:03:17.640
even though they don't
see it in the front.

60
00:03:17.640 --> 00:03:21.820
They can still go and see it in the back,
and you might want to remove that.

61
00:03:21.820 --> 00:03:24.410
So in this episode,
we're gonna be talking about

00:03:24.410 --> 00:03:28.370

then how to inspect a document to

00:03:28.370 --> 00:03:32.567

We'll also talk about accessibility,

67
00:03:39.365 --> 00:03:41.455
>> Yeah, yeah, and
it's all in the same place.

68
00:03:41.455 --> 00:03:43.172
So that's where we'll just

69

>> Well, wow, okay, well, how about we

And we're gonna open up a file

74
00:03:57.449 --> 00:04:00.366
I gotta put a picture of a bunny in there,
it's either a bunny or

76
00:04:01.423 --> 00:04:02.619
>> It's a very, very unbirthday thing.

77

>> [LAUGH] Now I'm gonna

78
00:04:04.984 --> 00:04:07.047
>> Yeah, I know,
song's in your head forever now.

79

I can see the actual scene in the movie,

81
00:04:13.025 --> 00:04:17.916
All right, so, now we're gonna talk

the file or the backstage view.

83
00:04:19.955 --> 00:04:21.593
It's over here in the info,

84

the info is on by default when you

00:04:25.361 --> 00:04:29.507
But just in case,
make sure you are on the info section.

86

And so, over here, I have properties like

87
00:04:35.840 --> 00:04:40.160
All of these are ones that I have added,
if I opened up, let's say,

even a file that I already have created,

which is here, tocindex, and

Notice that there isn't a title,
there isn't a tag, and

there's not gonna be any of the same

92
00:04:57.359 --> 00:05:03.870
Okay, so in the document properties added,
hence the name, I put that all in there.

00:05:03.870 --> 00:05:06.760
So I put in word, properties, fields,

00:05:06.760 --> 00:05:11.280

00:05:11.280 --> 00:05:14.500

I put a title, and actually,
yeah, some of these fields and

these properties, they tie indirectly

00:05:28.210 --> 00:05:31.300
We've talked about fields

In the Word Advanced series,

00:05:34.840 --> 00:05:37.560
and specifically, with those cover pages,

00:05:37.560 --> 00:05:40.640

00:05:40.640 --> 00:05:43.420
Well, it's pulling from

So they do work together in other

00:05:48.423 --> 00:05:52.670
hey, I wanna put this

And if I scroll on down through here,

[LAUGH] Ive talked about this

I did it last week and
Ill turn it in tomorrow.

00:06:16.168 --> 00:06:19.077
Well, I could come into here and see like,
no, you didn't create it last week.

113
00:06:19.077 --> 00:06:21.174
>> [LAUGH]
>> You created it just the other day.

00:06:21.174 --> 00:06:22.052

115
00:06:22.052 --> 00:06:24.075
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, when you told me, so

this whole created days is information

And these authors, I have Lance and

At the very end,

00:07:16.478 --> 00:07:21.300
But there's even more that you could

00:07:21.300 --> 00:07:23.470

00:07:33.420 --> 00:07:36.120

modified and things like that.

139
00:07:45.050 --> 00:07:48.850
The summary of where I typed

140
00:07:48.850 --> 00:07:50.630
the comments, if I wanted to.

141
00:07:51.930 --> 00:07:53.360
The statistics is kinda fun.

142
00:07:53.360 --> 00:07:57.131
I just wanna see, okay, well, how many
characters that I use, how many words.

143
00:07:57.131 --> 00:07:59.756
Now, we have all of this
within the status bar, but

144
00:07:59.756 --> 00:08:02.151
it's nice to have it in
one particular place.

145
00:08:02.151 --> 00:08:07.502
The number of revisions, wow, I've done
this I did 13 provisions on this document.

146
00:08:07.502 --> 00:08:08.297
I didn't even know that.

147
00:08:08.297 --> 00:08:09.970
[LAUGH] That's kinda fun.

148
00:08:09.970 --> 00:08:14.660
And then you can also create
custom tags and custom metadata,

149
00:08:14.660 --> 00:08:19.020

to include within this document.

150
00:08:19.020 --> 00:08:23.100
And that's where you could go up and

151
00:08:23.100 --> 00:08:27.410
Now I also have had people say that
what they do is they have specific

152
00:08:28.670 --> 00:08:30.400

153
00:08:30.400 --> 00:08:35.915
They always have to have the company name
and the different tags or the title.

154
00:08:35.915 --> 00:08:38.651
So if these are things that,
like will always be the same for

155
00:08:38.651 --> 00:08:41.773
every single document you create,
you could always fill this in and

156
00:08:41.773 --> 00:08:44.263
then make your own template,
you can do File Save As.

157
00:08:44.263 --> 00:08:47.396
And change this template and
then use that to create, and

158

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne show you how to customize the Word User Interface(UI) to suit your personal tastes. Specific customizations covered here includes: customizing the Ribbon, custom keyboard shortcuts, editing options, printing options, and more.
episodes.title: Customize Interface
